Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to establish fundamental relationships between molecular scale surface modification and macroscale interfacial adhesion and fracture. The research program will emphasize the development of integrated, multiscale experimental and numerical tools to characterize, model, and ultimately expand understanding of how self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) can be exploited to control mechanisms of interfacial failure, with emphasis on the high strain rate regime at which experimental conditions and molecular-level models can be directly related. The experimental assessment of the strength and toughness of the SAM-mediated interfaces will be achieved through advances in high strain rate, laser-induced dynamic delamination methods. To support the experiments and provide insight on the interfacial failure processes, advanced modeling tools combining molecular dynamics models and a continuum-level multiscale cohesive framework will be developed, validated, and applied. The novel integration of MD and continuum-level cohesive models of delamination will deliver important insights on the molecular tailoring of adhesion properties in delamination events.

The research project will have significant educational and technological impact. SAMs are increasingly used in a wide range of technological applications, including lubricants in MEMS, diffusion barriers in microelectronics, adhesion promotion, and for control of heat transport across interfaces. Assessing and predicting the adhesion properties of SAMs are critical for successful performance in these and future applications. This research project will provide training for two graduate students and one summer undergraduate research student, who will benefit from a truly multidisciplinary education in materials science, solid mechanics, and chemistry and will have the opportunity to participate in outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) provide an enabling platform for modifying the chemical and physical properties of a surface in an on demand fashion. This project was a combined experimental and computational investigation into the complex relationships between molecular scale surface modification and macroscale interfacial adhesion and fracture.  The research resulted in the (1) development of new high strain-rate test methods to accurately measure the changes in adhesive strength and interfacial fracture energy for different surface modification with SAMs, (2) the extension of molecular-based multiscale simulation strategies to assess the impact of SAMs on the high-strain-rate strength and toughness properties of model interfaces, (3) use of these combined numerical and experimental tools to understand how to modify surfaces to control interfacial fracture toughness and (4) education, mentoring and training of three graduate students and three undergraduate researchers.  

 

Intellectual merit:  Through integrated development of multiscale experimental and numerical tools, this research has demonstrated how surface modification (SAMs) can be exploited to control mechanisms of interfacial failure, with emphasis on the high strain rate regime at which experimental conditions and molecular-level models can be directly related.  The investigation focused on transfer printed gold films on substrates functionalized with several commercially available SAMS with different termination chemistries.  Strength and toughness of the SAM-mediated interfaces was achieved through advances in non-contact laser-induced spallation and dynamic delamination experimental method.  High strain rate adhesive failure of SAM-functionalized interfaces was generated at time scales approaching that of MD simulations with strain rates in excess of 107s-1 .  The results provide the first independent measurements of the strength and toughness of SAM-enhanced interfaces.  Advanced modeling tools that combine molecular dynamics models and a continuum-level multiscale cohesive framework were developed to support the experiments and provide insight on the interfacial failure processes.  The novel integration of MD and continuum-level cohesive models of delamination provided unique insight on the molecular tailoring of adhesion properties and the role of surface roughness in delamination events. The results are important for the design of commercial microelectronics, sensors, and microelectromechanical (MEMs) devices and inform on how to modify surfaces for optimal interfacial fracture properties, especially in the dynamic regime for which no data was previously available.  

 

Broader impacts: This project has resulted in the completion of one female Ph.D. student, who is now an Asst. Professor at the University of Kentucky.  She is starting a research program on biomaterials that directly utilizes the experimental techniques developed under this project.   Two additional graduate students are both on track to finish their Ph.D degrees in the coming year.  In addition, three undergraduate research students also participated in the research. One successfully completed her B.S. degree in Material Science and Engineering and is now working in industry.  A second undergraduate completed her degree in Nuclear Plasma, and Radiological Engineering and is currently in graduate school at the University of Pennsylvania. A third undergraduate completed hi degree in Aerospace Engineering and is now attending graduate school at Georgia Tech University.  All of these students were able to benefit from a multidisciplinary research experience involving materials science, solid mechanics and chemistry.  They also had the opportunity to participate in a broad range of outreach activities.

Modified by: Nancy R Sottos

  • Molecular modeling and experimental characterization of the effect of different molecular surface modifications on interfacial strength.
    University of Illinois
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Molecular Modification of Surfaces for Control of Interfacial Fracture
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) provide an enabling platform for modifying the chemical and physical properties of a surface in an on demand fashion. This project was a combined experimental and computational investigation into the complex relationships between molecular scale surface modification and macroscale interfacial adhesion and fracture. The research resulted in the (1) development of new high strain-rate test methods to accurately measure the changes in adhesive strength and interfacial fracture energy for different surface modification with SAMs, (2) the extension of molecular-based multiscale simulation strategies to assess the impact of SAMs on the high-strain-rate strength and toughness properties of model interfaces, (3) use of these combined numerical and experimental tools to understand how to modify surfaces to control interfacial fracture toughness and (4) education, mentoring and training of three graduate students and three undergraduate researchers. Intellectual merit: Through integrated development of multiscale experimental and numerical tools, this research has demonstrated how surface modification (SAMs) can be exploited to control mechanisms of interfacial failure, with emphasis on the high strain rate regime at which experimental conditions and molecular-level models can be directly related. The investigation focused on transfer printed gold films on substrates functionalized with several commercially available SAMS with different termination chemistries. Strength and toughness of the SAM-mediated interfaces was achieved through advances in non-contact laser-induced spallation and dynamic delamination experimental method. High strain rate adhesive failure of SAM-functionalized interfaces was generated at time scales approaching that of MD simulations with strain rates in excess of 107s-1 . The results provide the first independent measurements of the strength and toughness of SAM-enhanced interfaces. Advanced modeling tools that combine molecular dynamics models and a continuum-level multiscale cohesive framework were developed to support the experiments and provide insight on the interfacial failure processes. The novel integration of MD and continuum-level cohesive models of delamination provided unique insight on the molecular tailoring of adhesion properties and the role of surface roughness in delamination events. The results are important for the design of commercial microelectronics, sensors, and microelectromechanical (MEMs) devices and inform on how to modify surfaces for optimal interfacial fracture properties, especially in the dynamic regime for which no data was previously available. Broader impacts: This project has resulted in the completion of one female Ph.D. student, who is now an Asst. Professor at the University of Kentucky. She is starting a research program on biomaterials that directly utilizes the experimental techniques developed under this project. Two additional graduate students are both on track to finish their Ph.D degrees in the coming year. In addition, three undergraduate research students also participated in the research. One successfully completed her B.S. degree in Material Science and Engineering and is now working in industry. A second undergraduate completed her degree in Nuclear Plasma, and Radiological Engineering and is currently in graduate school at the University of Pennsylvania. A third undergraduate completed hi degree in Aerospace Engineering and is now attending graduate school at Georgia Tech University. All of these students were able to benefit from a multidisciplinary research experience involving materials science, solid mechanics and chemistry.
